Electrocatalytic conversion of nitrate to ammonia (NITRR) can simultaneously achieve the removal of nitrate and the synthesis of value-added ammonia, a promising candidate to replace Haber-Bosch process with low carbon dioxide emissions. However, high hydrogenation energy barrier for *NO intermediates and insufficient supply of active hydrogen cause slow hydrogenation process, and further result in low efficiency of nitrate conversion and ammonia synthesis. Herein, a series of tandem catalysts, one-dimensional coordination polymers (1D CCPs) with dual sites are synthesized and obtained 190.4 mg h–1 mgcat –1 ammonia production rate with Faradaic efficiency of 97.16%, outperforming to the most of recent reported catalysts. The catalytic performances are well-maintained even after a long-term stability test of 1200 h, laying the foundation for practical applications. Density functional theory results reveal that the stationary adsorbed *NO on Ni site induced proximity electronic effect could reduce the energy barrier for hydrogenation of *NO intermediates over Cu site. In addition, the Ni site in the dual sites 1D CCPs is conducive to generating active hydrogen, providing rich proton source to boost the hydrogenation of *NO, and further enhancing the compatibility of deoxygenation and hydrogenation process. Our work paves a new insight into the mechanism of NITRR process and will inspire more research interests in exploring the proximity electronic effect in catalytic process. Graphical Abstract The proximity electronic effect modulated the energy barrier for hydrogenation of *NO and the Ni site is conducive to generating rich proton source, promoting the hydrogenation process and balancing the processes of deoxygenation and hydrogenation. Keywords Electrocatalysis Ammonia synthesis Nitrate reduction Proximity electronic effect Dual sites 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is one of the most important chemical feedstocks and a potential carbon-free energy carrier as well as hydrogen carrier [ 1–7 ]. The conventional Haber-Bosch process causes significant energy consumption and CO2 emissions [ 8,9 ]. As a potential alternative, electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction (NITRR) enables the production of green ammonia under mild conditions and remediation of nitrate contaminants [ 10–13 ]. Numerous catalysts, including metal [ 12,14 ], metal oxide [ 10 ], complex [ 15,16 ] and single atom [ 11,17 ], have been synthesized and exhibited promising NITRR activity. However, low ammonia yield and insufficient stability have limited the practical application. The NITRR involves complex multi-step deoxygenation and hydrogenation processes. The faster deoxygenation and slower hydrogenation processes result in the failure of real-time hydrogenation of generated nitrogen-oxygen intermediates, leading to a lower efficiency of nitrate conversion to ammonia [ 18,19 ]. Therefore, it is essential to regulate the kinetic matching degree of these two processes to reduce the energy barrier of the rate-determining step (RDS) and promote the catalytic conversion efficiency. One-dimensional π-d conjugated coordination polymers (1D CCPs) have garnered significant interest in the field of electrocatalysis due to their well-defined structure, high thermal/chemical stability, high density isolated active sites and excellent electrochemical performance [ 20–27 ]. The clear structures of 1D CCPs facilitate the analysis of structure-activity relationship. Additionally, tandem catalysts are always employed to improve the catalytic performances through the synergistic effect of multiple active sites, including single atom catalysts [ 28–30 ], alloy [ 31–33 ] and composites [ 34–36 ]. On the one hand, multiple active sites are more conducive to the multistep proton-coupled electron transfer process [ 37,38 ]. On the other hand, the doping of hetero-metal sites may break the intrinsic symmetrical charge distribution and manipulate the electronic properties of adjacent site by proximity electronic effect. Both charge distribution symmetry breaking and proximity electronic effect are able to modulate the interactions between catalytic centers and intermediates [ 39–42 ]. In the view of NITRR, it is necessary to integrate the site with excellent NITRR activity and the site with Hads production in one catalyst. Previous researches reveal that Cu site has lower dissociation energy barriers for nitrogen-oxygen intermediates (*NO3, *NO2, and *NO, etc.) and shows relatively high NH3 synthesis selectivity at lower negative potentials [ 43,44 ]. While Ni site exhibits excellent performance in water dissociation, possessing outstanding O–H activation capability and strong Hads adsorption capacity [ 45–50 ]. Therefore, it is highly desirable that dual sites 1D CCPs with both Ni and Cu sites allow for the effective balance of nitrate deoxygenation, and hydrogenation processes during the NITRR process, which has not been reported yet. In this work, we synthesized seven different 1D CCPs Ni x Cu y -BTA using a hydrothermal method by adjusting the Cu ratio. Among these catalysts, Ni1Cu1-BTA exhibited the best NITRR performance, achieving a high ammonia production rate of 190.4 mg h–1 mgcat –1 with a high Faradaic efficiency of 97.16% at –0.8 V (vs. RHE), surpassing the majority of recently reported NITRR catalytic performances. After a long-term stability test of 1200 h, Ni1Cu1-BTA maintained excellent catalytic performance and achieved gram-scale ammonia recovery. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated that the proximity electronic effect induced pre-adsorption of *NO species on both Ni and Cu sites could effectively decrease the energy barrier of *NO → *NHO over adjacent Cu or Ni sites, which was the rate-determining step for NITRR process. Particularly, the ΔG RDS over Cu site in NiCu-BTA decreased to 0.01 eV, greatly promoting the catalytic conversion of nitrate to ammonia thermodynamically. Furthermore, the Ni site in the dual sites 1D CCPs is conducive to generating active hydrogen, providing rich proton source to boost the hydrogenation process, and effectively improve the catalytic conversion efficiency. Additionally, the assembled Zn-NO3 − battery exhibited power density of 5.9 mW cm–2, with ammonia production rate of 1.61 mg h–1 cm–2 at 16 mA cm–2 and Faradaic efficiency of 95.36%. The proximity electronic effect in this work paves new insights into the mechanisms behind NITRR process and will inspire more research interests in tandem catalysts for multistep electrocatalytic reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Cu-BTA The CuSO4·5H2O (0.20 mmol, 49.9 mg) was dispersed in a mixture of 10 mL deionized water and 2 mL concentrated ammonia solution, followed by sonication for 10 min. Subsequently, the resulting CuSO4 solution was dropwise added into 10 mL BTA·4HCl (0.20 mmol, 56.8 mg) solution. The mixtures were stirred at room temperature for 3 h. After completion of the reaction, the mixtures were filtered, and the residues were washed at least three times with deionized water, acetone, and ethanol. Finally, the obtained solid was vacuum-dried at 60 °C for 12 h, and the resulting powder was named as Cu-BTA. 2.2 Synthesis of Ni-BTA The synthesis method was the same as for Cu-BTA, with the substitution of CuSO4·5H2O with NiCl2·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 47.5 mg). The obtained powder was named as Ni-BTA. 2.3 Synthesis of NixCuy-BTA Highly crystalline Ni-BTA (0.2 mmol, 38.6 mg) was used as precursor and dispersed in 10 mL ethanol solution and sonicated for 10 min. Subsequently, the resulting Ni-BTA solution was dropwise added to a 10 mL ethanol solution containing 0.2 mmol of CuSO4·5H2O (49.9 mg). The mixed solution was transferred to a 50 mL hydrothermal autoclave reactor with polytetrafluoroethylene and reacted at 80 °C for 12 h, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. After completion of the reaction, the mixtures were filtered, and the residues were washed at least three times with deionized water, acetone, and ethanol. Finally, the obtained solid was vacuum-dried at 60 °C for 12 h, and the resulting powder was named as Ni1Cu1-BTA. By varying the molar ratio of Ni and Cu salts in Ni-BTA solution and CuSO4·5H2O solution to 5:1, 2:1, 1:2, and 1:5, four other 1D CCPs materials were synthesized using the same method, and named as Ni5Cu1-BTA, Ni2Cu1-BTA, Ni1Cu2-BTA, and Ni1Cu5-BTA, respectively. 2.4 Preparation of electrode A 0.5 cm × 0.5 cm hydrophilic carbon cloth was treated with oxygen plasma for 15 min. Subsequently, 2 mg of M-BTA catalyst was added to a mixed solution containing 1800 μL of ethanol and 200 μL of a 5 wt% Nafion solution. The mixtures were sonicated for 20 min to form uniform ink. Then, 100 μL of the M-BTA ink was drop-cast onto the carbon cloth (0.1 mg catalyst), resulting in catalyst loading amount of 0.4 mg cm–2. The prepared electrode was dried naturally. 2.5 Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction In the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate, the cathode compartment contained 50 mL of 0.1 mol L–1 KNO3 and 1 mol L–1 KOH solution, while the anode compartment contained 50 mL of 1 mol L–1 KOH solution. Prior to conducting the nitrate electro-reduction test, cyclic voltammetry testing was performed. The voltage was scanned within the range of –1.0 to –2.0 V vs. Hg/HgO, at a scan rate of 10 mV s–1, and the scan was repeated multiple times until the cyclic voltammetry (CV) polarization curve stabilized. Linear sweep voltammetry testing was then carried out within the voltage range of 0 to –2.0 V vs. Hg/HgO, at a scan rate of 10 mV s–1. Subsequently, a constant potential polarization test was conducted for 1 h from –0.5 to –1.3 V vs. RHE. For long-term stability testing, a continuous electrocatalytic test system was set up, equipped with 1 L electrolyte reservoirs. A peristaltic pump drove the exchange of the electrolyte between electrolysis cell and electrolyte reservoir, which was refreshed every 20 h. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy tests were performed in a solution containing 0.1 mol L–1 KNO3 and 1 mol L–1 KOH, within a potential range from –0.17 to –0.42 V (vs. Hg/HgO), a frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz, and a voltage amplitude of 5 mV. CV tests were conducted at different scan rates of 50, 100, 150, 200, 250, and 300 mV s–1 within the potential range of no redox reaction (–0.35 to –0.45 V vs. Hg/HgO), and the double-layer capacitance values were calculated. The voltages applied during the experiment were relative to the Hg/HgO electrode, and can be converted to the voltage relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode as following: E RHE = E Hg/HgO + 0.0591 × pH + 0.098 2.6 Computational details The spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed by the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [ 51,52 ]. The projector-augmented wave (PAW) method was employed for description of electron-ion interactions, with a kinetic energy cutoff of 450 eV. The generalized gradient approximation expressed by Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) was adopted as the exchange-correlation functional. The weak van der Waals interaction was included by using Grimme’s dispersion correction (DFT-D3) [ 53 ]. The explicit solvation effect wasn’t taken into consideration since the energy influence was negligible based on the previous studies [ 54,55 ]. Instead, the implicit solvation model (a polarized continuum model as implemented in VASPsol) is adopted with dielectric constant of 80 [ 56 ]. The CuNi-BTA was constructed as one-dimensional lattice, with vacuum slab of 20 Å along y- and z-direction, with a 3 × 1 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point sampling in the reduced Brillouin zone. All the structures were fully relaxed until energy and force reached the threshold value of 1 × 10–5 eV and 0.02 eV Å−1, respectively. Nitrate reduction includes a series of elementary steps, as well established in recent studies [ 57–59 ]. The thermodynamics was evaluated by calculating free energy change (ΔG) along the reaction pathway, which can be obtained by ΔG = ΔE + ΔZPE − TΔS, where ΔE is the electronic energy difference obtained by DFT calculations, ΔZPE is the difference of zero-point energies, and TΔS is the entropy contribution at room temperature (298.15 K in this work). For all intermediate states, ZPE and S were calculated by frequency calculations as described in earlier work [ 60 ]. The free energy of a proton-electron pair was considered as half of the free energy of isolated H2 in the gas phase, according to the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [ 61 ]. The liquid-phase corrections were applied for the liquid-phase molecules involved as product (–0.09 eV for H2O and –0.104 eV for NH3), based on the investigations by Koper and Calle-Vallejo [ 62,63 ]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterizations of M-BTA Nickel chloride coordinated with 1,2,4,5-benzenetetraamine tetrahydrochloride (BTA·4HCl) in dilute ammonia solution at room temperature to form Ni-BTA. Subsequently, partial nickel ions in Ni-BTA were substituted by copper ions through a hydrothermal process involving ions exchange, forming dual sites Ni x Cu y -BTA (Fig. 1(a) ). By varying the amount of Cu2+, a series of Ni x Cu y -BTA catalysts with different Ni/Cu molar ratios were synthesized. The Fourier transform Infrared spectrum (FT-IR) showed that BTA ligand exhibited two characteristic peaks attributed to the N–H stretching vibrations of the primary amine at around 3350 cm−1 and peaks at around 1600 cm−1 attributed to skeleton vibration of benzene ring (Fig. 1(b)). In FT-IR of all the synthesized Ni x Cu y -BTA, the N–H stretching vibration peaks of the primary amine disappears while skeleton vibration peaks of benzene ring remain, indicating the successful formation of one-dimensional conjugated coordination polymer chains (Fig. 1(c)). The XRD patterns revealed that Ni-BTA displays three characteristic diffraction peaks at 20.8°, 23.9°, and 29.4°, corresponding to d-values of 4.25, 3.73, and 3.08 Å, respectively. In contrast, the crystallinity of Cu-BTA was relatively poor, with weak diffraction peaks observed at 17.46°, 23.65°, and 28.42°. When small amounts of Cu ions were doped into Ni-BTA, lattice expansion occurred, leading to the shift of the diffraction peaks towards lower angles (Fig. 1(d)). However, when the doping amounts of Cu ions were excessively high, phase separation occurred in Ni1Cu5-BTA, resulting in similar crystalline morphology to that of Cu-BTA. The morphology and microstructure of the catalysts were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Ni-BTA exhibits a stacked nanorod morphology (Figs. 2(a), (b) ), and after the hydrothermal process involving the introduction of Cu ions, the formed Ni1Cu1-BTA maintained nanorod morphology, but the ordering of the stacking was reduced (Figs. 2(c), (d)). Similar changes were observed for Ni5Cu1-BTA, Ni2Cu1-BTA, and Ni1Cu2-BTA. When the content of copper ion was excessively high, Ni1Cu5-BTA exhibited noticeable aggregation of the nanorods (Figs. S1, S2). Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping (Fig. 2(e)) demonstrated the uniform distribution of Cu, Ni, C, and N elements, further confirming the successful doping of Cu. X-ray photoelectron spectroscope (XPS) was employed to investigate compositions of Ni x Cu y -BTA as well as interactions between Cu and Ni. The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum of Ni x Cu y -BTA exhibited two characteristic peaks attributed to –C=N (396.9 eV) and –C–N (398.2 eV), indicating electronic redistribution between N atoms due to d-π conjugation between the metal ions and the ligand (Figs. S3-S7). Additionally, characteristic signals of Cu 2p further confirmed the successful doping of Cu. The binding energy of Ni 2p peaks in Ni1Cu1-BTA (2p 1/2: 871.6 eV, 2p 3/2: 854.3 eV) decreased by 0.5 eV compared to those in Ni-BTA (2p 1/2: 872.1 eV, 2p 3/2: 854.8 eV) (Fig. 3(a) and Fig. S8(b)). While the binding energy of Cu 2p in Ni1Cu1-BTA exhibited a notable positive shift and an increase in binding energy compared to Cu-BTA (Fig. 3(b) and Fig. S8(e)). These results indicated that electrons transferred from Cu sites to Ni sites due to the doping of Cu ions, generating interactions between Cu and Ni sites [ 64–67 ]. In Ni1Cu1-BTA, the electron density around Cu sites decreased, favoring the adsorption of negatively charged NO3 – from the aqueous solution, while the electron density around Ni sites increased, favoring the adsorption of positively charged H3O+, potentially playing a synergistic role in the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate. To investigate the elemental oxidation states and coordination environments of Ni1Cu1-BTA, synchrotron-based X-ray absorption spectroscopy tests were conducted. The Ni absorption edge of Ni1Cu1-BTA was situated between Ni foil and NiO, close to NiO, indicating that the average oxidation state of Ni in Ni1Cu1-BTA is slightly less than +2 (Fig. 3(c)). The slight decrease in the oxidation state of Ni ions was likely due to the partial transferred electrons from Cu sites to Ni sites, consistent with previous XPS results. Although the partial electrons transferred from Cu sites to Ni sites could lead to an increase in the oxidation state of Cu ions, the strong reducing properties of amine groups in ligand partially reduced Cu ions, generating partial cuprous ions. Therefore, there were two kind of Cu ions in Ni1Cu1-BTA (Cu2+ and Cu+, Fig. 3(b)), and the average oxidation state of Cu ions lied between 0 and +2. The Cu absorption edge of Ni1Cu1-BTA was located between the absorption edges of Cu foil and CuO (Fig. 3(e)), further suggesting that the average valence state of Cu lay between 0 and +2. Fourier transformed the Ni K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data of Ni1Cu1-BTA to R space using k3-weighted χ(k) functions. There was a single scattering path at approximately 1.47 Å (Fig. 3(d)), close to the Ni–N scattering path in NiPc (1.44 Å), indicative the existence of Ni–N bond. Similarly, the single scattering path of Cu at 1.60 Å in Ni1Cu1-BTA was similar to the Cu–O bond in CuO (1.60 Å) and the Cu–N bond in CuPc (1.63 Å), indicating Cu–N bonds in Ni1Cu1-BTA (Fig. 3(f)). Additionally, the Ni and Cu scattering paths in Ni1Cu1-BTA also included signals at 2.21 and 2.30 Å, close to the Ni–Ni (2.06 Å) and Cu–Cu (2.24 Å) scattering paths in Ni and Cu foil, indicating the presence of Ni–Ni/Cu bonds and Cu–Cu/Ni bonds in Ni1Cu1-BTA, albeit with differences from Ni and Cu foil. Further analysis of the EXAFS data through wavelet transforms (WT, Figs. 3(g)–(n)) revealed that the WT signals of Ni–Ni and Cu–Cu bonds in Ni and Cu foil focused around k-space shift of approximately 7.3 Å–1. In contrast, the WT signals of Ni–Ni/Cu bonds and Cu–Cu/Ni bonds in Ni1Cu1-BTA appeared at higher k-space shifts, like the WT signal of the Cu–Cu bond in CuPc. Overall, it can be inferred that in Ni1Cu1-BTA, Ni and Cu ions coordinate with amine groups on ligand, forming Ni–N bonds and Cu–N bonds. Additionally, because of the large amont of aromatic rings and good planarity in 1D CCPs, there may be π-π stacking interactions between neighboring chains like those in NiPc and CuPc molecules, with metal atoms from different chains coming into proximity, as evidenced by the scattering path signals around 2.2 Å for Ni–Ni/Cu and Cu–Cu/Ni bonds in the EXAFS data. 3.2 Electrocatalytic NITRR performances The NITRR electrocatalytic performances of synthesized Ni x Cu y -BTA catalysts were evaluated using an H-type electrolysis cell. The reactant NO3 –, as well as the main products NO2 – and NH3 in the electrolyte, were detected using UV-vis spectrophotometry. From the linear sweep voltammetry curve (LSV, Fig. 4(a) ), it was evident that the current density of Ni1Cu1-BTA significantly increased upon the addition of KNO3 to the electrolyte, attributed to the reduction of NO3 –. The NITRR performances of different Ni x Cu y -BTA catalysts with varying Ni/Cu molar ratios were investigated in 1 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte containing 0.1 mol L–1 NO3 – (Fig. 4(b)). The incorporation of Cu ions led to significant enhancements in the ammonia yield rate, reaching the maximum at Ni/Cu molar ratio of 1:1. As the amount of doped Cu continued to increase, the ammonia yield rate started to decrease. This could be ascribed to insufficient Hads generation when Ni content was low, failing to meet the subsequent hydrogenation of NO3 – adsorbed on Cu sites, resulting in a decrease in ammonia yield rate. Additionally, excessive Cu doping could lead to phase separation, generating partial Cu-BTA, which may influence the synergistic effect during the catalytic process, further reducing ammonia yield rate. The Faradaic efficiencies for ammonia of all synthesized Ni x Cu y -BTA catalysts showed minor differences, ranging between 80%–90%. Ni1Cu1-BTA was chosen for further studies owing to its highest current density and catalytic activity (Fig. S9(a)). With applied potential increased, the NH3 yield rate gradually increased, primarily due to the higher polarization current density, providing more abundant electrons for the reduction reaction, reaching a maximum value of 230.43 mg h–1 mgcat –1 at –1.3 V vs. RHE. Furthermore, within the applied potential range, the Faradaic efficiency displayed a volcanic trend, increasing initially and reaching a maximum of 90.16% at –0.9 V vs. RHE, followed by a significant decrease in FE with further increase in voltage, mainly attributed to the intensified hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) (Fig. 4(c)). Therefore, –0.9 V vs. RHE was chosen as the optimal operating voltage. N2H4 and NH2OH were undetectable under all reaction conditions (Fig. S10). Compared to Ni-BTA and Cu-BTA, Ni1Cu1-BTA exhibited significantly enhanced NH3 yield rates throughout the entire applied potential range (Fig. 4(d)), with the NITRR current density of Ni1Cu1-BTA (~880 mA cm–2) at –0.9 V vs. RHE far surpassing that of Cu-BTA (~620 mA cm–2) and Ni-BTA (~470 mA cm–2) (Fig. S9(a)). This further confirmed that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni enhanced the NITRR performances. The NH3 yield rate and FE of Ni1Cu1-BTA exceeded those of most reported electrocatalysts (Fig. 4(e) and Table S1). To assess the efficiency of Ni1Cu1-BTA in nitrate removal, we conducted a continuous 12 h catalytic experiment and monitored the changes in nitrate, nitrite, and ammonia concentrations throughout the process. As the reaction time increased, the concentration of nitrate steadily decreased, reaching a conversion rate of 94.1% after 12 h. Meanwhile, the concentration of ammonia gradually increased, while the concentration of the by-product NO2 – remained consistently low. This indicated that Ni1Cu1-BTA exhibited high selectivity towards the synthesis of ammonia through nitrate reduction. In the initial stages of the reaction, the high concentration of nitrate led to a rapid reaction rate and a swift increase in ammonia concentration. As the reaction prolonged and the nitrate concentration continued to decrease, the inhibitory effect on HER weakened, resulting in a deceleration of the reaction rate and a slow increase in ammonia concentration. After 8 h of reaction, due to the lower nitrate concentration, less ammonia was produced through reduction, and HER dominated the electrocatalytic process, leading to the overflow of generated NH3 in the electrolyte, causing a slight decrease in the concentration of ammonia (Fig. 4(f)). A series of control experiments (Fig. 4(g)) were conducted to confirm that NH3 was indeed generated through the NITRR process. These experiments included using pure KOH solution at the optimal operating voltage and utilizing 0.1 mol L–1 KNO3 electrolyte for NITRR at open circuit voltage (OCV). The NH3 yield rates detected in both sets of control experiments were negligible, indicating that our reaction system did not introduce contamination of ammonia. Additionally, we performed isotope labeling experiments and detected NH3 using 1H NMR. When 14NO3 – was used as the reactant, the 1H NMR spectrum of the product exhibited three characteristic signal peaks. Conversely, when 15NO3 – was used, only two characteristic signal peaks were observed. These observations were in accordance with the 1H NMR spectra of (14NH4)2SO4 and (15NH4)2SO4 solutions (Fig. 4(h)). This result indicated that the detected NH3 originated from the conversion of NO3 –. As the reduction time increased, the intensities of the 14NH4 + and 15NH4 + peaks concurrently increased, further confirming that the generated ammonia originated from the reduction of nitrate (Fig. 4(i) and Fig. S11). Furthermore, calibration curves were established using maleic acid as an internal standard (Fig. S12), and the NH3 yield rate obtained through UV-vis and 1H NMR methods were close (Fig. S13), demonstrating the reliability of both quantitative detection methods. Long-term stability of electrocatalyst were significant to practical applications. We established an electrocatalytic cycling test system equipped with 1 L electrolyte reservoirs, driven by peristaltic pump to exchange electrolyte between electrolytic cell and electrolyte reservoir, which was renewed every 20 h (Fig. S14). Ni1Cu1-BTA exhibited excellent stability over 1200 h of continuous operation at a voltage of –0.9 V vs. RHE, with no significant decrease in average current density (> 0.75 A cm–2), ammonia yield rate (> 149 mg h−1 mgcat −1), and Faradaic efficiency (> 86%). After catalytic reactions, the stacked nanorod morphology and the composition of Ni1Cu1-BTA were well maintained (Figs. S15, S16, Table S2), demonstrating a good balance between catalytic activity and long-term stability (Fig. 4(j)). To further expand the applicability of the Ni1Cu1-BTA catalyst, the NITRR performances under various nitrate concentrations, initial pH value of electrolyte, and temperatures were investigated. Within the range of 0.01 to 1 mol L–1 nitrate concentrations, the NH3 production rate increased significantly from 27.07 to 196.93 mg h–1 mgcat –1, with an ammonia FE reaching 97.16% in 0.5 mol L–1 NO3 – electrolyte, indicating the suitability of Ni1Cu1-BTA across a broad range of nitrate concentrations. The notable decrease in FE at 0.01 mol L–1 NO3 – was attributed to intense competition from HER, while the slight decrease at ultra-high concentration of NO3 – (1 mol L–1) may be due to insufficient Hads provided by water decomposition, affecting the nitrate hydrogenation process (Fig. S17(a)). Across the pH range of 2 to 14, Ni1Cu1-BTA maintained excellent catalytic activity (Fig. S17(b)), demonstrating its broad pH tolerance. Furthermore, we studied the impact of temperature variation on NITRR performances. Within the range of 10 to 40 °C, as the temperature increased, the NH3 production rate increased while the FE remained at high level, indicating that elevated temperatures have a promoting effect on nitrate reduction (Fig. S17(c)). The long-term stability of Ni1Cu1-BTA, its broad applicability across nitrate concentration ranges, pH tolerance, and its adaptability to temperature changes, all hold significant importance for the practical application of Ni1Cu1-BTA. Solar energy is one of the most abundant, clean, and sustainable energy sources on Earth. Effectively harnessing solar energy is of significant importance in meeting the growing global energy demand, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and achieving sustainable development. Therefore, we constructed a solar-driven nitrate reduction system for ammonia production. Notably, under sunlight, 280 mA current was achieved for nitrate reduction, effectively converting nitrate to NH3 (Fig. S18(a)). The produced NH3 was removed from the solution by gas purging, captured using HCl to obtain NH4Cl solution, and subsequently processed through rotary evaporation and drying to yield NH4Cl(s). XRD pattern (Fig. S18(b)) confirmed the high purity of the recovered NH4Cl(s). Solar-driven nitrate reduction to ammonia and the recovery of high-purity NH4Cl(s) were realized. 3.3 Mechanism of electrocatalytic NITRR To investigate the differences in the electrocatalytic performances of Ni x Cu y -BTA with different Ni/Cu molar ratio, a series of electrochemical characterizations were conducted. According to the LSV curves, dual-metal 1D CCPs Ni x Cu y -BTA exhibited significantly higher current densities compared to single-metal 1D CCPs (Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA), with Ni1Cu1-BTA displaying the highest current density in 0.1 mol L–1 KNO3 (Fig. S19). The higher current density implied that more electrons were available for nitrate reduction. Additionally, the Tafel slope of Ni1Cu1-BTA was only 98.25 mV dec–1, much smaller than that of Ni-BTA (284.42 mV dec–1), Ni5Cu1-BTA (130.93 mV dec–1), Ni2Cu1-BTA (117.54 mV dec–1), Ni1Cu2-BTA (128.64 mV dec–1), Ni1Cu5-BTA (153.31 mV dec–1) and Cu-BTA (270.57 mV dec–1) (Fig. S19(b)), indicating that Ni1Cu1-BTA possessed the fastest kinetic characteristics. To further confirm the origin of the excellent NITRR performances of Ni1Cu1-BTA, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) in both 1 mol L–1 KOH and 0.1 mol L–1 KNO3 + 1 mol L–1 KOH electroytes was calculated by measuring the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) in the non-Faradaic region. In KOH solution, the C dl values of Ni-BTA, Cu-BTA, and Ni1Cu1-BTA were 2.26, 1.99, and 2.57 mF cm–2, corresponding to ECSA values of 56.5, 49.75, and 64.25 cm2, respectively (Fig. S20). Similarly, in the 0.1 mol L–1 KNO3 + 1 mol L–1 KOH solution, the ECSA values for Ni-BTA, Cu-BTA, and Ni1Cu1-BTA were 52.25, 57.25, and 65.5 cm2, respectively (Fig. S21). In KOH solution, Ni-BTA exhibited higher ECSA than that of Cu-BTA, indicating that Ni-BTA exposed more active sites for adsorbing H2O molecules during the HER process. Once nitrate was added in electrolyte, the ECSA of Cu-BTA and Ni x Cu y -BTA increased while that for Ni-BTA decreased, indicating that NO3 – was more likely to be adsorbed on Cu sites and H2O tended to be reduced on Ni sites. Moreover, Ni1Cu1-BTA exhibited higher ECSA than both Ni-BTA and Cu-BTA, indicating more NITRR active sites for Ni1Cu1-BTA. In addition, in-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed to investigate the kinetics of the HER and NITRR reactions of Ni1Cu1-BTA. In 1 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte, the R ct values of Ni1Cu1-BTA and Ni-BTA were significantly lower than that of Cu-BTA, indicating that Ni1Cu1-BTA and Ni-BTA exhibit faster charge transfer characteristics than Cu-BTA for HER (Fig. S22, Table S3). In contrast, in the 0.1 mol L–1 KNO3 + 1 mol L–1 KOH solution, the R ct values of Ni1Cu1-BTA and Cu-BTA were significantly lower than that of Ni-BTA, suggesting that Ni-BTA has lower charge transfer efficiency than Cu-BTA and Ni1Cu1-BTA for NITRR (Fig. S23, Table S4). Additionally, Ni1Cu1-BTA possessed lower R ct value than that of Cu-BTA, indicating the charge transfer efficiency during NITRR were significantly improved by the *H supply from Ni sites, which promoting the hydrogenation of nitrogen species adsorbed on Cu sites. In order to explore the intermediates generated during NITRR, we employed differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) for in-situ detection. Initially, the catalyst ink was spread onto a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) membrane, exposing its backside to the detection system connected to the mass spectrometer (MS), allowing various gaseous products to enter the mass spectrometry detection system for analysis. We conducted three consecutive potential scan cycles (each cycle ranging from 0 to −1.3 V vs. RHE) and recorded the variation of mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) signals over time. Signals corresponding to m/z = 17, 30, 33, and 46 were detected, corresponding to NH3, NO, ONH3, and NO2 species, respectively (Fig. 5(a) ). Among these signals, the signal for ammonia was the strongest, while the signals for other intermediates were relatively weaker, consistent with the higher selectivity towards ammonia observed in NITRR process. Combining the in-situ Raman spectroscopy and in-situ infrared spectroscopy, we gained a comprehensive understanding of the various intermediate species formed on the catalyst surface during NITRR process. The peak at 1341 cm−1 in in-situ Raman spectra (Fig. 5(b)) could be attributed to *NO2 –, confirming the presence of the intermediate product NO2 –. The peak at 1050 cm−1 belonged *NO3 –, and its vibrational peak intensity increased as the applied voltage increased in low potential range. Once the applied voltage exceeded –0.7 V vs. RHE, the vibrational peak intensity decreased, indicating that the rapidly reduction of adsorbed NO3 − at higher voltages. The Raman peaks at 712 and 1140 cm−1 corresponded to characteristic signals of NH3 adsorbed on the surface of catalyst. The peak intensity of adsorbed NH3 was relatively weak, implying that the generated NH3 could promptly desorb, facilitating the rapid and continuous progression of NITRR process. In the in-situ FT-IR spectra (Fig. 5(c)), the peaks around 1688, 1603 and 1555 cm–1 attributed to the N−O stretching vibration [ 10,68,69 ]. As the potential increased from OCV to –0.9 V, the appearance and gradually increase of the *NH2 intermediate at 3329 cm−1 demonstrated the continuous protonation process of NO3 − [ 70 ], the rapid and continuous generation of NH3 during NITRR process. Additionally, we carried a series of control experiments. Once electrolyte was replaced by K15NO3, the corresponding characteristic peaks shift to lower wavenumbers (3308 cm−1 for N−H vibration, 1657, 1582 and 1497 cm−1 for N−O vibration, Fig. S24(a)) because of the isotope effect [ 71 ]. The characteristic peaks of N−H and N−O vibrations disappeared when using pure KOH as electrolyte (Fig. S24(b)). When using pure carbon cloth as working electrode, only relatively weak vibration signals were observed as a result of poor catalytic performance of carbon materials. During the NITRR process, adsorbed *H on the catalyst surface could undergo three pathways: dimerized into H2 molecules, participated in the hydrogenation process of N-containing intermediates adsorbed on the catalyst (*NO2, *NO, *N, etc.), or desorbed from the catalyst surface into the solution to form H· radicals. To further validate the crucial role of *H in the reduction of nitrate to ammonia, we conducted electron spin resonance (ESR) tests using 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) as an H· radical trapping agent. When DMPO-H was formed, the ESR spectrum displayed nine typical signals, with intensities close to a 1:1:2:1:2:1:2:1:1 ratio, and the signal intensity was directly proportional to the concentration of DMPO-H. In the absence of KNO3, both Ni1Cu1-BTA and Ni-BTA exhibited strong DMPO-H signals (Figs. 5(d), (e)), indicating their strong capability to dissociate H2O and generate abundant H· radicals. Moreover, the DMPO-H signal intensity of Ni-BTA was higher than that of Ni1Cu1-BTA, suggesting that the partial replacement of Ni with Cu led to a reduced ability to dissociate H2O and generate *H. This phenomenon indicated that Ni sites possessed a stronger ability to dissociate H2O and generate *H. With the concentrations of KNO3 increased, the DMPO-H peak intensities of Ni1Cu1-BTA and Ni-BTA gradually decreased, indicating that a large amount of generated *H was utilized for the hydrogenation of NO3 −, providing solid evidence for the involvement of *H in NITRR process. After the addition of 100 mmol L−1 KNO3, Ni-BTA still exhibited significant DMPO-H signals, while almost all DMPO-H signals disappeared in Ni1Cu1-BTA, suggesting that *H was consumed more slowly on Ni-BTA but could be rapidly consumed on Ni1Cu1-BTA. This further confirmed that Cu sites were more favorable for adsorbing N-containing intermediates and that the subsequent hydrogenation process consumed a large amount of *H. To further evaluate the hydrogenation capability of the catalyst in the NITRR process, we compared the DMPO-H signal intensities of Ni1Cu1-BTA and Ni-BTA corresponding to different KNO3 concentrations (Fig. 5(f)). Clearly, the decay rate of DMPO-H signal intensity on Ni1Cu1-BTA was much faster than that on Ni-BTA, with Ni1Cu1-BTA having a decay rate constant k of 829.29, 1.21 times that of Ni-BTA (683.55). The faster consumption of *H on the surface of Ni1Cu1-BTA indicated that *H generated at Ni sites during the NITRR process could promote the hydrogenation of N-containing intermediates (*NO2, *NO, *N, etc.) adsorbed at Cu sites, accelerating the generation of NH3. To gain comprehensive understandings on NITRR catalytic performance by CuNi-BTA, DFT calculations were carried out. The structures of CuNi-BTA were checked by DFT simulations first. There are three possible stacking configurations, CuNi-BTA-1 with AA stacking, CuNi-BTA-2 with AB stacking, and CuNi-BTA-3 without overlapping. For the surface catalysis, we constructed bilayer CuNi-BTA as substrates (Fig. 6(a) ). The calculation results indicated that CuNi-BTA-2 had the lowest energy among the three configurations and moderate interlayer distance of 4.15 Å. Therefore, the CuNi-BTA-2 was chosen as the substrate for NITRR catalysis in the following calculations. In previous work [ 22 ], we have found that the hydrogenation of *NO to *NHO on the active Cu site was the rate determining step for the NITRR catalyzed by 1D CCP Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA. To simplify the reaction steps considered, we used *NO as the key intermediate and compared the adsorption strength of NO molecule on monolayer CuNi-BTA (ML-CuNi-BTA), bilayer CuNi-BTA (BL-CuNi-BTA), bilayer Cu-BTA (BL-Cu-BTA) and Ni-BTA (BL-Ni-BTA) with AA stacking. It was evident to see that the double metal CuNi-BTA exhibited stronger adsorption to the NO molecule than that of single metal Cu-BTA and Ni-BTA, for both Cu and Ni sites (Fig. 6(b)). When comparing bilayer CuNi-BTA with bilayer Cu-BTA/Ni-BTA (Fig. 6(c)), it was found that the charge density on the metal atoms was hardly influenced when forming the double-metal BTA. However, by assigning the Bader charge, it was revealed that both the Cu and Ni atom would obtain more electrons from the adjacent BTA fragment, with slightly decreased positive charge. As a result, the enhancement in NO adsorption should be mainly ascribed to the less positive charge in the CuNi-BTA. Additionally, the enhanced van der Waals interaction from the sublayer also made partial contributions when comparing monolayer CuNi-BTA with bilayer CuNi-BTA. The reaction pathways of NITRR on the Ni and Cu site in BL-CuNi-BTA were calculated separately (Figs. 6(d)−(g)). As been verified in previous work, the free energy changes (ΔG) from *+NO3 to *NO were always downhill on all kinds of M-BTAs [ 22 ]. Thus, the ΔG values of intermediates from *+NO3 to *NO were not mentioned. Based on our calculation results, it was confirmed that for the individual Ni or Cu site in BL-CuNi-BTA, they exhibited highly similar reaction pathway with those of Ni-BTA and Cu-BTA. The step (*NO → *NHO) acted as rate-determining step (RDS), and the obtained NITRR limiting potential (UL) were −0.16 and −0.04 V for the Ni and Cu site in BL-CuNi-BTA, respectively. These values were almost the same with that in the as-reported single-metal Cu-BTA (−0.03 V) and Ni-BTA (−0.15 V) [ 22 ]. The DFT calculation results demonstrated that the enhanced NITRR catalytic performance observed in BL-CuNi-BTA could not originate from the enhanced NO adsorption on the separate catalytic site. Considering that the co-existence of *NO on both Cu and Ni site was possible, we assumed a pre-adsorption mechanism, based on which an adjacent metal site was pre-adsorbed by a NO during the NITRR process. Different from the single-metal system where the NITRR on adjacent site required the same extra potential to overcome the energy barrier during RDS, the Ni and Cu site in CuNi-BTA exhibited different NO adsorption strength and ΔG for activation of *NO. When *NO was generated at both the Ni and Cu sites, there may existed synergistic effect that was different from the single-metal BTAs. We have considered the NITRR pathway on the *NO pre-adsorbed sites. It was revealed that following the same reaction pathway, both the Ni and Cu site in CuNi-BTA benefited from the pre-adsorption mechanism (Figs. 6(d)−(g)). When the Cu site was pre-adsorbed, the UL of NITRR occurred on Ni site was decreased to −0.07 V. When the Ni site was pre-adsorbed, the U L of NITRR occurred on Cu site was decreased to −0.01 V. Considering that the Ni site in CuNi-BTA exhibited both stronger NO adsorption strength and higher ΔG for activation of *NO than that of Cu site, the Ni site was easier to be occupied by a generated NO molecule, and at lower applied potential the Cu site could reduce the *NO preferentially. The DFT calculations clearly indicate that the formation of dual sites 1D CCPs was favorable for enhancement of both the Cu and Ni site when comparing with the single-metal ones, and the pre-adsorption mechanism was the plausible reaction mechanism. 3.4 Extended application: Zn-NO3 battery Inspired by the excellent catalytic activity of Ni1Cu1-BTA in NITRR, we assembled a Zn-NO3 − battery with Ni1Cu1-BTA as the cathode catalyst and zinc plate as the anode. During the discharge process of Zn-NO3 − battery, the dissolution of zinc at the anode driven the NITRR at the cathode (Fig. 7(a) ). The Zn-NO3 − battery exhibited a stable OCV of approximately 1.18 V vs. Zn (Fig. 7(b)). The discharge polarization curve of the Zn-NO3 − battery using Ni1Cu1-BTA as the cathode catalyst demonstrated an increase in output current density as the cathode potential became more negative (Fig. 7(c)). Power density was another important parameter for the battery, reaching a peak power density of 5.9 mW cm−2 at 0.38 V vs. Zn2+/Zn in 1 mol L−1 KOH + 0.1 mol L−1 KNO3 electrolyte. When the Zn-NO3 − battery was discharged at different current densities of 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, and 24 mA cm−2, the discharge voltages were 0.51, 0.39, 0.30, 0.24, 0.18, and 0.16 V vs. Zn, respectively, while the discharge plateau remained essentially stable, indicating its excellent electrochemical stability (Fig. 7(d)). The assembled Zn-NO3 − battery achieved a high NH3 generation rate of up to 1.61 mg h−1 cm−2 at 24 mA cm–2 and an FE of up to 95.36% at 16 mA cm–2, outperforming most reported catalysts (Fig. 7(e) and Table S5). During a 72 h charge-discharge cycling process at a constant current density of 4 mA cm−2, the Zn-NO3 − battery maintained stable voltage output (Fig. 7(f)), demonstrating its outstanding charge-discharge stability and durability. The assembled Zn-NO3 − battery operated at a discharge current density of 16 mA cm–2 for 12 h, exhibiting stable output voltage, ammonia production rate, and FE, indicating excellent long-term stability of this battery system (Fig. 7(h)). To validate the practicality of the Zn-NO3 − battery, we connected two Ni1Cu1-BTA-based Zn-NO3 − batteries, which successfully powered a light-emitting diode (Fig. S25). The constructed Zn-NO3 − battery achieved the “three birds with one stone” goal, simultaneously realizing efficient ammonia synthesis, removal of nitrate pollutants, and electrical energy output. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we synthesized dual sites one-dimensional coordination polymer chain with different Cu/Ni ratios by introducing Cu into Ni-BTA through hydrothermal method. The as-synthesized catalysts were employed for investigating the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate to ammonia. The dual sites 1D CCPs effectively balanced the processes of nitrate adsorption, deoxygenation, and hydrogenation in NITRR, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. Among them, Ni1Cu1-BTA exhibited the best performance in NITRR, achieving high ammonia yield rate of 190.4 mg h–1 mgcat –1 and Faradaic efficiency of up to 97.16%, surpassing the catalytic performance of most reported catalysts in NITRR. Even after 1200 h of catalytic reaction, Ni1Cu1-BTA maintained excellent catalytic performances and enabled the recovery of gram scale NH4Cl. DFT calculation results revealed that pre-adsorption of *NO induced by proximity electronic effect on neighboring site effectively reduce the energy barrier of hydrogenation process thermodynamically. In situ spectroscopy, ESR, and DEMS indicated that the active hydrogen generated from the Ni sites by H2O splitting promoted the hydrogenation of N-containing intermediates adsorbed on Cu sites, thereby enhancing the overall activity of nitrate reduction to ammonia. Additionally, we assembled Zn-NO3 – battery with Ni1Cu1-BTA as the cathode and zinc plate as the anode, which exhibited an OCV of 1.18 V and a power density of 5.9 mW cm–2. At a current density of 16 mA cm–2, the ammonia production rate and Faradaic efficiency were 1.61 mg h–1 cm–2 and 95.36%, respectively. The constructed Zn-NO3 – battery achieved the “three birds with one stone” goal, simultaneously realizing efficient ammonia synthesis, removal of nitrate pollutants, and electrical energy output. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic conversion of nitrate to ammonia (NITRR) can simultaneously achieve the removal of nitrate and the synthesis of value-added ammonia, a promising candidate to replace Haber-Bosch process with low carbon dioxide emissions. However, high hydrogenation energy barrier for *NO intermediates and insufficient supply of active hydrogen cause slow hydrogenation process, and further result in low efficiency of nitrate conversion and ammonia synthesis. Herein, a series of tandem catalysts, one-dimensional coordination polymers (1D CCPs) with dual sites are synthesized and obtained 190.4 mg h–1 mgcat –1 ammonia production rate with Faradaic efficiency of 97.16%, outperforming to the most of recent reported catalysts. The catalytic performances are well-maintained even after a long-term stability test of 1200 h, laying the foundation for practical applications. Density functional theory results reveal that the stationary adsorbed *NO on Ni site induced proximity electronic effect could reduce the energy barrier for hydrogenation of *NO intermediates over Cu site. In addition, the Ni site in the dual sites 1D CCPs is conducive to generating active hydrogen, providing rich proton source to boost the hydrogenation of *NO, and further enhancing the compatibility of deoxygenation and hydrogenation process. Our work paves a new insight into the mechanism of NITRR process and will inspire more research interests in exploring the proximity electronic effect in catalytic process.
